overview: This subject extends on the skills provided in Introduction to Improvisation. Through practical activities in workshop-style classes, instrumentalists and singers explore musical improvisation in solo and group contexts through demonstrations, deep listening exercises and challenging performance tasks.

Tailored to suit their instrument or voice, students engage in activities that extend strategies for improvising across diverse musical styles, with a particular focus on jazz improvisation, harmonic, melodic and rhythmic tools inherent in standard jazz repertoire, and the protocols of solo and group performance in a jazz context.
This subject is designed for music students who have traditionally focused on performing notated music.
This subject is available for enrolment to students in all the Bachelor of Music Majors except Jazz and Improvisation.
ilo: collaborate with and respond creatively to other musicians in group performance contexts;
perform solo improvisations using appropriate motivic, melodic, harmonic and/or rhythmic tools;
interpret and apply appropriate chord tones, extensions, alterations and modes to harmonic progressions from standard jazz repertoire;
create and perform an improvised solo on a jazz standard.
generic_skills: respond openly and imaginatively to new ideas;
apply critical thinking, analytical and problem-solving skills to unfamiliar challenges;
engage in rigorous and respectful debate;
show interest in and respect for others.

Prerequisites.content: Students must meet one of the following requisite options:
Admission into the D-MUSIC Diploma in Music

Admission into one of the following: Composition major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music, Interactive Composition major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music, Musicology & Ethnomusicology major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music, Music Studies major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music, Performance major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music, Performance (ANAM) major in the B-MUS Bachelor of Music

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: One 3-minute solo performance (with accompaniment) applying melodic and rhythmic concepts over harmonic progressions
Compose, notate and perform a solo on a jazz standard
One 3-minute performance on a jazz standard (with accompaniment)

assessment.hurdle: Students must attend a minimum of 75% of all scheduled classes and performances as directed.

date_times.contact_hours: 18 hours, comprising one 90-minute practical class per week.
18 hours, comprising one 90-minute practical class per week.
